data.event: The village's name was spelled Crauudene in the 1086 Domesday book - it is derived from the Old English crawe and denu, meaning 'valley of the crows'.
The parish is now known as Croydon, but it used to be called 'Croydon-with-Clopton' or 'Croydon-cum-Clopton' - In 1086, about 28 peasants lived at Croydon.
The parish is now known as Croydon, but it used to be called 'Croydon-with-Clopton' or 'Croydon-cum-Clopton' - In 1086, about 28 peasants lived at Croydon.

The separate vills of Croydon and Clopton were joined in 1561 and Croydon's population may have increased to around 140 people early in the 17th century, but fell to 90 during the reign of Charles II.
Open fields surrounding Croydon village were inclosed for pasture around 1640, but from the late 18th century arable farming recommenced.
Some timber-framed houses dating from the late 17th or early 18th centuries still stand, though most of the cottages date from the early 19th century.

event.title: became the A603 and it has now

data.event: The track, called 'Royston road', was improved and incorporated into the Cambridge-Biggleswade turnpike, later became the A603 and it has now been downgraded to the B1042.
Croydon Old Lane, in the north, went towards Hatley, while the current road up Croydon Hill to Hatley was first built in 1830.
